A1: Educators can get their students to understand the why behind their learning through applying the things they are learning to everyday life skills. An example of this is when talking about measuring stuff you tie it in to how we measure stuff when we bake. #Satchat

A1: Doing what you say, being available, being a good listener is a start. Relationships contribute to a Positive Culture. Get to know staff more than their job description! They have families, special interests, and more. It’s important to see the “whole staff member” #satchat

A2. Complexity and deep learning require new standards. “Elaborative rehearsal is the opposite of rote memorization - the opposite of “do the worksheet” where everything is the same except for the specific numbers” https://medium.com/teachers-on-fire/the-baseball-metaphor-3a5893d73323… #satchat

A1. Power of connection: What do we owe our learners. “Clarity” must go both directions, and that requires that we offer our students our complete attention (and our acceptance, access, and the abundance childhood requires) #satchat

A1 Energy comes from being authentic. Not acting like everything is great when it isn't, but also not emphasizing everything is bad when it isn't. I think a lot of students think the later & it demoralizes them #satchat

When I'm told that the 'real world' requires us to make children do things, as that's what their life will be like, then I ask why. In response I get fury. Then I wonder whether perhaps I am the feared catastrophe, the one who just won't shut up and do as she's told. 11/

Could it be that those children might ask why the system has to be this way? Could it be that they might demand change? Could it be that they might make others uncomfortable with their honesty? Could it be that they won't learn to conform? 10/

When people tell me that children need to spend their school years being made to do things, in practice for adulthood, I wonder what their fear is. What catastrophe would happen if we didn't expect children to do things 'because I say so' & let them make more choices? 9/

Childhood could be filled with exploration, learning and fun, because children should not have to worry about putting food on the table. The purpose of work is to get the work done, the purpose of education is for young people to learn. Those aims are different. 8/

Even if we do accept that most of adulthood is spent doing things that we have to do, it doesn't follow that childhood must be the same.Childhood is a once in a lifetime opportunity. It's different because children don't have adult responsibilities & they have lots to learn.7/

For some young people, school is fine because they enjoy it, they feel valued & it has meaning for them. For others it isn't okay. For them, there is no purpose. The only reason becomes 'because you have to'. And most humans don't like being made to do things. They resist. 6/

This is different to many children at school. No pay, no chance to decide whether what they do is valuable to them, and it doesn't matter if they enjoy it. They can't leave. They are there because others tell them they must be there and that there are no other options. 5/
